title-group.article-title: Book review: Cognitive Development: An Advanced Textbook

bio.title: Biographies
bio.p: Belle Wallace is Director of TASC International (TASC: Thinking Actively in a Social Context). She has been editor of Gifted Education International. (AB Academic Publishers) since 1981. She was Co-Director of the Curriculum Development Unit (University of Natal, SA) with the double brief for developing Assessment Strategies and Curriculum Extension for very able, disadvantaged learners, and training Curriculum Planners; she edited ‘Worldwide Perspectives on Gifted Disadvantaged’ in 1993 (AB Academic Publishers), and the second volume (with Gillian Eriksson) Diversity in Gifted Education: International perspectives on global issues (Routledge) was published in 2006; she now works as a consultant on Problem-solving and Thinking Skills both nationally and internationally. Her publications are many: most recently, she has published a series of 6 Problem-solving and Thinking Skills books extending topics taken from the National Curriculum Framework (UK) (published by NACE/Fulton). Recently, Belle has been a made a Fellow of the Royal Society for the encouragement of Arts (UK) in recognition of her service to education.

Michael F. Shaughnessy is currently Professor of Educational Studies at Eastern New Mexico University in Portales, New Mexico. He has been a teacher, coach, guidance counselor, school psychologist and University Professor. He has written, edited, or co-edited more than 12 books and published more than 500 articles, interviews, book reviews and research studies. His research interests include intelligence testing and personality assessment of gifted children.

article-meta.product:
Bornstein Marc H.
Lamb Michael J.
(eds), Cognitive Development: An Advanced Textbook. New York NY: Psychology Press 2011

body.p: Cognitive developmental science offers essential perspectives on human development and is a major intellectual endeavour because it enables us to more fully understand the processes and influences that impinge on key aspects of neuroscience, perception, cognition, and language.

This new text is superbly organized and supplies cutting-edge research, theories, and analysis. Each chapter reflects on the current state of the field in cognitive development with an introduction as a forward organizer; a brief overview of the specific field; a concluding chapter summary; and relevant and current references for further reading. Readers will be delighted with the text’s online resources, website features, glossary of key terms and concepts, and hotlinks to journal articles.

Part 1 presents the foundations of developmental science – the concepts and theories of human development, the interaction between culture and development, and an analysis of research design and measurement.
Part 2 examines developmental neuroscience, psychophysiology, and genetics; physical and motor development; perceptual development; cognitive development; and language development.

Cognitive Development provides excellent reading for both graduate and postgraduate study. The book has a wealth of notable contributors and has been extremely well organized so that the reader can select appropriate chapters according to a particular interest or can absorb the complexity of the whole current approach of developmental cognitive science.
The book is indeed a library of resources, and makes a superb reference book in itself, as well as indicating avenues for further reading and research.
